discourse_list.title: MIP65: Monetalis Clydesdale: Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution

content.content: MIP65: Monetalis Clydesdale: Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution  Preamble MIP#: 65 Title: Monetalis Clydesdale: Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution Author(s): @Allan_Pedersen Contributors: Tags: Type: Proposal Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-02-09 Date Ratified: 2022-05-23 Dependencies: MIP21 Replaces: None Forum  URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip65-project-clydesdale-monetalis-arrangement-i-liquid-bond-strategy-execution/13148 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmXHM6us#poll-detail   References  Investing our liquidity in short-term ETF, managing PSMs exposures ALM framework for MakerDAO MIP6 Collateral Onboarding Application: Stable+; US Treasury Securities Up To 12 Months Duration MIP13c3-SP12: Declaration of Intent - Invest in short-term bonds MIP68: Monetalis Lusitano: UK Green Economy SME Wholesale Lending Monetalis Evolution   Sentence Summary MIP65 will onboard and activate a RWA vault for the purpose of acquiring USDC via PSM and investing them in high quality liquid bond strategies held by a trust arranged and maintained by Monetalis.  Paragraph Summary MIP65 onboards a RWA vault that will acquire USDC via the PSM and invest them in approved bond strategies. This MIP, importantly, also set out strict conditions for the setup of the underlying legal and governance structure and verification requirements. The proposal should be seen as connected with MIP68 in accordance the strategy outlined in Monetalis Evolution  Component Summary MIP65c1: Legal Structure & Asset Strategy Conditions of the Collateral Onboarding This component sets out the verification mechanism and conditions ensuring appropriate collateral is onboarded using an appropriate legal structure and governance framework using an appropriate technical solution. MIP65c2: Technical Conditions of the Collateral Onboarding This component contains the technical requirements for unambiguous technical execution of the collateral onboarding  Motivation  USDC is a large single-asset exposure on Maker’s balance sheet - and pays no yield. We believe that working with professional bond managers and starting a diversification strategy can, and should, be implemented with priority. From the many discussions and proposals on the Maker forum on this topic, we believe there is solid consensus in the Maker Community on the necessity and desirability of this course of action. As of today, substantive efforts and work have been undertaken on many fronts related to this type of situation within CU’s, the protocol, the Maker Community and Monetalis. This MIP set out a clear path for combining these efforts and work output into an execution hereof.   Specification / Proposal Details  MIP65c1: Legal Structure & Asset Strategy Conditions of the Collateral Onboarding Legal structure and Governance Monetalis will set up a legal trust structure, and governance framework, with the necessary contractual relationships and legal protections to make it appropriate to act as large scale RWA collateral for Maker. This includes, but is not limited to:  No ability by third parties or Monetalis to access the funds or change the terms of the legal structure Maker Governance has complete ability to trigger a liquidation with a successful executive vote encoding an instruction to the trustee of the structure. It should not be possible for a single third party to block the ability of Maker Governance to make decisions or modify the structure. There must be no apparent weak links or edge cases that allow funds to get misappropriated or stuck. An Asset Purchase and Allocation Restriction, ensuring only appropriate bond assets and strategies can be acquired by the structure All surplus generated by the legal structure must be manually sent to the Maker surplus buffer every quarter. A Monetalis fee of 0.15% of AuM deployed p.a. paid quarterly.  This above established structure must set up a relationship with a regulated crypto broker, and an ETH address must be emitted that can be used to construct the smart contracts necessary to complete the next step of the onboarding process specified in MIP65c2. Legal Structure and Governance Appropriateness Verification The Real World Finance Facilitator and the “in SES incubation” Facilitator of Legal and Transactions Services must, through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the legal and governance structure appropriateness for holding a large amount of low risk real world asset collateral for Maker. Asset Purchase and Allocation Restriction Verification The Strategic Finance Facilitator must, also through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the Asset Purchase and Allocation Restriction ensuring that only execution of bond strategies appropriate to use as large scale liquid RWA collateral can be acquired with assets provided to the legal structure by Maker. Technical Verfication The Collateral Engineering Services Facilitator must, again through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the technical appropriateness of the MIP21 designed solution in accordance with the Collateral Onboarding process (“COB”). Should one such Verification not be forthcoming, for whatever reason, this MIP will not move forward in the COB.  MIP65c2: Technical Conditions of the Collateral Onboarding The technical implementation must follow the MIP21 framework. Upon Collateral Engineering Services solution Verification in MIP65c1, the relevant smart contracts must be constructed and deployed. It should hardcode the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure specified in MIP65c1, and follow the MIP21 framework. These smart contracts must only allow for the generation of Dai through a vault that is sent to the ETH address of the legal structure as its ultimate destination, and it must not be technically possible to send the Dai elsewhere, in accordance with MIP21. There must also not be any additional technical features or complexity that goes beyond the minimum necessary smart contracts and dummy constructs to enable the generation of Dai and its transfer to the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure. The ability to initiate the generation of Dai from the vault and trigger their transfer to the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure is given to an Ethereum address controlled by Monetalis. This address must have no ability to access the funds. When the collateral onboarding process for MIP65 has progressed to step 7 in the COB, an executive vote must be created (or code must be bundled into a broader executive vote) that activates all permissions for the vault to be onboarded based on the smart contracts specified in MIP65c2. The vault must provide:  Debt Ceiling of DAI 500 million. Stability Fee of 0% (surplus is paid manually through the legal structure, as specified in MIP65c1.) All other parameters must be set to ensure they have no functional impact.

content.content: Is this envisioned as one thing or a portfolio of things? Thank you

I believe there is a lot of value in structuring and facilitating the onboarding of a top notch, institutional, asset manager able to act within a Segregated Mandate to diversify and manage Maker’s liquidity. We have now enough the scale and sophistication to attract the best counterparts. To clarify, managing a treasury book of 100s of MM or B is VERY DIFFICULT and not territory for the uninitiated. I am looking forward to hear more about this proposal. I believe Monetalis (and other platforms) can help the community immensely. One thing I want to add though. With Moentalis also pitching itself to be a large scale / deep tech / structured credit investor, I struggle to see how the two proposals can coexist. Developing a platform able to originate 100s of MM of structured credit by onboarding alt platforms requires 10s of people, financial resources, and a lot of time in order to build the tech stack. I am unconvinced Monetalis could deliver on both front simultaneously. Given the date of publication of this MIP, I believe that this implies @Allan_Pedersen believes Clydesdale to be the most productive competitive position for Monetalis. I am therefore looking forward to hear more and contribute in any possible way in what is one of the most important initiatives for the Maker community.

content.content: UPDATE 1 We have spent the past few weeks exploring the possibilities of strategy and investment opportunities etc and can give you some ideas of what we have uncovered and what might be achievable in the short term. We continue to work with CU’s on establishing what would be a reasonable allocation size to an off-chain liquid bond strategy. More to come on that. Overall, our findings of what is achievable today for Maker seem quite positive in our view.  FINDINGS  Operational Structure: Positive Outlook As a starting point we have, in discussion with asset managers, to make the discussions direct and practical, suggested Maker could reuse a structure similar to Monetalis BVI (or other offshore jurisdiction) trust including our selection of bank and trustee etc… Obviously with appropriate refinement as the “Maker Governance Package” (i.e. role of trustee/attestors/vote etc) gets cleared up. The main sticking points in this structure, in discussing with TradFi institutions, are often origin of capital (i.e. minted DAI/USDC origins etc) and the beneficiary/UBO (MKR holders/MakerDAO), but several seem willing to try and work with this and find practical solutions. We found this a clear positive. It helped substantially that we had actual real parties we could point to from our work in Monetalis with practical operational solutions to reference, and that we could share these with the contacted asset managers. And it very much helped that we could discuss from a “peer point of view”, as ourselves being a potential RWA vault partner to Maker via our Monetalis Green lending proposal and our time working with the Maker community. These were key aspects, in fact, in getting very practical with the asset managers fast. I suspect the above positive effect are indeed what was, somewhat, predicted by a number of community members in proposing the Arranger model. Hats off to them.  Strategy: Evolving…but picture forming! Here’s a list of the ideas/recommendations from speaking to various asset managers and banks etc. A picture is slowly starting to form, but still more discussions to be had with these parties and with the various interested CU’s.   Barbell strategy best to accomplish liquidity/security/yield in today’s market (late credit cycle) Consistently the suggestion is that to accomplish both yield and liquidity, there needs to be a component that is (fx government bonds) secure, interest-rate sensitive and liquid, but returning close to no yield at this moment - and then another part of the portfolio that is focused on yield in the longer-term (fx corporate bonds of investment grade). Such a strategy may include a diversification mix of maturities, borrower types, geography, theme focus and investment ratings. We are pursuing further evidence of this strategy’s appropriateness. Just for illustration of a Barbell strategy see this picture:  880×499 24 KB    Multi-Manager focus General expectation is that not one single asset manager would take on the entirety of such a portfolio. It would be multiple. Seems so far a credible concept.   ETF Platform as “Base” General recommendation to gain access to an ETF universe and utilise this as a one of the bases for a strategy. A good set of the funds are reasonably liquid and allow for moving funds between strategies/choices quickly. One could potentially imagine the low risk/liquid end of the barbell to be primarily supported via such an ETF platform.   ESG Every single asset manager we have spoken to has some sort of ESG scoring/evaluation included - just unfortunately generally not in easily comparable formats. How to fit this together from multiple asset managers into a consistent evaluation is to be determined.   Stand-by Bank Credit Line? As we have emphasised the need for liquidity in times of market distress - be that during TradFi or DeFi market distress - the opinion we have heard from several is to develop a credit line with a major bank secured against the portfolio. The reason is that a) markets may close up in a situation of distress and b) moving in and out of portfolios due to short-term market distress could be very costly. As such it may make sense to secure a large bank credit line that can be deployed as needed within hours of need. I think we will explore this further in terms of possibilities and cost.    Investment Partners: High-quality Spectrum Emerging It seems very likely we can have fairly immediate access to the BlackRock ETF universe and relevant analysis instrumentation for strategy design. This illustration below is from 2019, but clearly there is some depth in this universe today - many with strong liquidity profiles. In terms of counterparty risk we think BlackRock scores quite well. Cost of access is an area of key consideration at this moment and we will explore further ASAP. We hope also to immediately start mapping various possible strategies within this universe for consideration and sharing with the community.  1137×840 134 KB  In addition, we have an increasing set of high-quality asset managers interested in providing part of the solution. We need a bit more work to be able to identify the asset managers and their specific suggestions before sharing with the community, but we can safely say that at least a few of these would certainly qualify as being of the same caliber and standing in the capital markets as BlackRock. To provide you some idea of what is being proposed, one such well-established asset manager (we have not been allowed to share name just yet before further discussions have taken place and certain checks made) provided the following starting point suggestion:  ASSET MANAGER ALPHA “…Our Credentials: Our strength in credit investing lies in the ability to identify the relatively small number of corporate bonds that will outperform the market over a long-term investment horizon. We believe that, over the long term, an issuer’s fundamental resilience will be reflected in the performance of its bonds and will prevail over shorter-term or sentiment-driven market fluctuations. Our in-depth analysis focuses on building a comprehensive understanding of a company’s long-term prospects and genuine diversity, based on deep knowledge of individual companies, allows for thoughtful risk taking. We have various strategies with long-term track records which demonstrate this ability to add value through individual bond selection. Sustainability analysis and ESG has become increasingly important in determining those companies which will thrive and we include as an appendix more details of our approach, which we believe is differentiated from many of our peers. Our Proposal: We believe our strengths align very well with the aims of MakerDAO as we understand them and include, as a core of our proposal, an actively managed long-term credit portfolio. This relatively short-dated and high-quality portfolio would deliver attractive levels of yield to compensate for some mark-to-market volatility. The credit portfolio may satisfy the requirements for the first tranche of collateral but as a complement, if desired, we could also add a carry module which aims to deliver more consistent returns and satisfy more pressing liquidity requirements. Further details are outlined below. A/ Credit module An actively managed portfolio representing our best ideas across global corporate bond markets. A relatively short-dated investment grade portfolio provides a balance of liquidity and low-probability of loss while still offering potential to add value through active credit selection. The current yield of this universe is around 2.3% with a spread above US treasuries of around 0.65%. Further work would be required to explore the most appropriate parameters, but a representative set of characteristics is as follows:     Benchmark ICE BofA 1-5yr US Corp Index     Target +0.75%-1.0% p.a. over rolling 3-year periods   Universe Global, fully hedged to USD   Credit quality Predominantly investment grade, c.20% budget for un-rated and sub-investment grade (mainly subordinated issuance of investment grade companies)   Maturity profile Predominantly short-dated, c.20% budget for > 5 years   Duration flexibility Predominantly short-dated, c.20% budget for > 5 years   Guideline holdings <100 issuers   Derivates Credit default swaps, interest rate swaps, futures     These parameters are based on guidance that MakerDAO would be most comfortable with an investment grade mandate. We would highlight that the traditional divide between investment grade and high yield is perhaps outdated, and there is very little increase in probability of default by moving down to BB-rated securities (but more pronounced moving down to B-rated). Our observation is that the greatest inefficiencies in credit markets exist in the ‘cross-over’ space covering BBB and BB-rated bonds, and the best opportunities for bond selectors exist when given the freedom to invest across this spectrum. Therefore, we believe the risk-return characteristics of this credit module would be improved if greater flexibility to invest in BB-rated bonds was allowed, say up to 30%. This would also provide more scope to protect against rising inflation. B/ Carry module A broad sub-3 years investment grade corporate bond buy-and-hold portfolio which provides a low-risk solution to enhance yield over cash. This portfolio has the advantage of combatting changes in overall yield environment through frequent re-investment. Liquidity screen and factor risk assessment control universe. A combination of each module could produce an absolute return style mandate with a cash-plus target….”  We have, of course, answered this proposal with a broad set of questions to understand further - and will facilitate the necessary checks mentioned above - such that more specifics and logic on these proposals can be shared with the community and more comprehensive discussion on the merits of the various proposals can be had. This was purely to provide you with a flavour of the type of ideas we are receiving from asset managers today.  Observations/Questions etc During the conversations we also experienced a number of questions and observations we are still processing, but list them here for conversation in short-form in no particular order:   Benchmarks? What to meet? What to beat? Across portfolio? Per strategy? Per asset manager? Index? Absolute?   How liquid? How big a liquidation discount is acceptable? Need cash within hours? Within days? Within weeks? Months? How big a percentage of the portfolio for each time category? And how big a loss willing to suffer for liquidity at each stage, if any?   Short-term mark-to-market volatility on long-term holdings? Appetite-level?   USD vs Non-USD hedged exposures? Appetite-level?   Investment-grade rating constraints vs dislocations in rating? Several asset managers point to exploitable credit inefficiency in cross-over space between BBB (IG) and BB (non-IG) - i.e. extra yield for limited lift in default probability. Appetite-level? (well illustrated in the example asset manager proposal above)   How to think about inflation in the portfolio?    Project Clydesdale Expected Outcome - as it is evolving now: So far, it looks like we should be able to develop, fairly fast, a flexible and scalable platform with broad access to the global bond markets via the ETF universe as well as directly to high-quality asset managers. This means a few things:   Multiple different strategies, with community support, can be executed on this platform   Asset Managers can be onboarded/off-boarded as determined by the community.   Given the scalability of this platform, it should, as far as I can tell, be able to support any levels of increased demands for DAI supply, only constrained by the size of the USD/DAI liquidity market.   Similarly, the platform should be able to support a temporary DAI “sell-off” with liquidity to buy DAI in a cost-efficient and time-sensitive manner - via potentially a credit line, ETF liquidations and ultimately asset manager position sales.   In short, Maker, this way, would be somewhat equipped as would usually a large life insurer or pension-fund in terms of asset access and be able to execute most ALM strategies via this. As such there is little direct innovation in the platform - the innovation will lie in the chosen strategies to executed on the platform to support an innovative ALM strategy. Hopefully, the establishment of this platform, can allow the community to focus much effort on the more innovative and impactful real-world-asset situations that aren’t available within the traditional investment universe expressed on this emerging platform.

content.content: Hi @Puzzler I am not quite sure how to answer this. I hope perhaps the update I have posted answers it? Otherwise please do let me know.

Hi @luca_pro, We remain committed to both MIPs. There are substantial synergies between the two. I promise to explain in a separate post over the next few days. Btw: Calling Monetalis deep-tech and large-scale are perhaps overly generous statements: our own wholesale lending management solution on AWS & growing lending to around USD 400M over 12 months does not quite qualify in todays world I fear. But I appreciate the sentiment!

content.content: Thank you for your answer @Allan_Pedersen. Me, and the rest of the community, are looking forward to hear more about your dual strategy. With limited resources and a wide range of action, I believe that a clear strategy will need to be provided to the community. I am particularly interested on your points about structuring. For what regards investment strategy, I believe that such decision should be left to the product factory, i.e. the asset manager, and not to the structuring intermediary. We are not inventing anything on the investment side. Large and reputable asset managers help financial and corporate institutions manage their treasury book every day. Maker, however, has a very peculiar structure and liquidity requirements that would require specialised structuring intermediaries (like Monetalis wants to become) and ALM analysts (we are seeing this attempt for specialisation happening within the Strategic Finance CU). Luckily, given the size of our liquid USDC-centred treasury book, I believe we can start implementing a solution and scale it up to a certain point without incurring in liquidity constraint. I am curious about the proposal from the asset manager but I am also nervous. A treasury portfolio should not, in principle, carry significant credit risk and a cross-over proposal IG-HY to squeeze a few bps of yield I believe doesn’t go in the direction of reserve diversification and yield improvement that an initial treasury portfolio should have. Summarising, I am looking forward to hear more but I would like to understand what is Monetalis position exactly, because I am confused. Is Monetalis?   A structurer, meaning that will provide the structure to Maker to access reputable asset managers remaining agnostic on strategy and partner?  An intermediary meaning that will provide structure but also onboard the partners  An asset manager itself meaning that it will ask for some level discretion in putting together the strategic and tactical asset allocation based on which the partners will behave  I believe those jobs to be fairly different. Whether the role of structurer/ intermediary could indeed have significant cross-overs across asset classes, being the discretion mainly at the asset manager level (below), the role of discretionary asset manager has very little scalability (unless Monetalis structure involves 100 people and a battle-tested tech platform) across rates and credit. Alternative credit origination, especially, is very time consuming even for a mere aggregator of existing platforms. Differently to what happens for listed securities, platform-originated credit is less standardised, presents spurious data, is very idiosyncratic when it comes to credit policies and quality of execution, and even being an aggregator of existing platforms requires a lot of work and man power. As a benchmark, large alternative credit originating platforms in Europe (I can provide examples if asked) that originate 500m of new loans per year are i) regulated by ECB/ local central banks, ii) have staff ranging between 50 and 100 people, iii) have spent several 10s of MM on proprietary tech platforms, iv) have at least 5 years of history - onboarding an originator typically requires 6 months of work, even before scaling deployment. Looking forward to continue the conversation. As the SES-incubated lead of the Lending Oversight CU I am working closely with RWF on the credit risk and structuring side of the equation, but based on experience and interest (and impact) I remain deeply interested on the evolution of our treasury management strategies as well.

content.content: Hi @luca_pro I have put the answers into sort of a “Qoute & Comment” format. I hope that helps.  Me, and the rest of the community, are looking forward to hear more about your dual strategy.  Sure! Of course. It will come shortly as promised.  With limited resources and a wide range of action, I believe that a clear strategy will need to be provided to the community.  I think you will find that, in practice, things are perhaps not as resource intensive as you imagine, but I will explain shortly - all as promised  I am particularly interested on your points about structuring.  Sure - I will include something on that in the update. You can also speak to @christiancdpetersen  - on these matters we are usually well aligned.  For what regards investment strategy, I believe that such decisions should be left to the product factory, i.e. the asset manager, and not to the structuring intermediary.  I do not believe I have ever said anything about Monetalis deciding any strategy if you are thinking about us as intermediary in your statement - in fact I believe I have made it crystal clear that the community must decide the strategy. And on whether the asset manager or the community decides strategy, well, that depends on what level of strategy you are talking about. Let’s say we wish to deploy an asset allocation strategy using the BlackRock iShares ETF universe - each iShares product has their own strategy. The picture below shows a few fixed income ESG Aware iShares - each with their distinct fixed income strategy:  1600×767 163 KB  So, obviously, nobody can have any impact on any of these individual iShares internal strategies - they are entirely in the hands of BlackRock. But choosing which of these above 7 strategies to buy into and how much to allocate into each - well that is - and should be - entirely in the hands of the community - and it should be driven by analysis of the liability side requirements and ultimately risk/return appetite of the community. We should of course ask advice from the asset managers (all advice is always welcome!) and ask them to run analysis on the possible asset allocation scenarios to understand potential/most likely behaviour in risk/return/volatility etc. That is essential. With other asset managers that allow customised strategies (such as Asset Manager A in the example), the community can be deeper involved in selecting more elements of the individual theme/category strategy (how much to allocate to IG rated vs non-rated - max Duration above 5y etc). Again - the asset manager must provide advice and analysis around these choices, but, ultimately, the decision will lie with the community on how to allocate and select. Maker has a unique liability side - that allows us to build a strategic advantage in thinking creatively about how to support it with an equally unique asset side. Proper ALM thinking must become a key focus and be built into a strategic advantage of Maker. It will prove us to be prudent in the eyes of regulators, will allow us to generate more yield, will allow us to build new DAI-based products etc etc. Done right, ALM will be an exceptionally strong competitive advantage that can fuel profitable growth of Maker. So Maker cannot resonably outsource, ultimately, these choices - but we should always be happy to gain advice and analysis from as many sources as possible - this can only lead the community to make better informed choices.  We are not inventing anything on the investment side. Large and reputable asset managers help financial and corporate institutions manage their treasury book every day.  Agreed.  Maker, however, has a very peculiar structure and liquidity requirements that would require specialised structuring intermediaries (like Monetalis wants to become) and ALM analysts (we are seeing this attempt for specialisation happening within the Strategic Finance CU).  As mentioned above, there are indeed uniquenesses that need to be deliberately turned into a competitive advantage - the sooner, the better.  Luckily, given the size of our liquid USDC-centred treasury book, I believe we can start implementing a solution and scale it up to a certain point without incurring in liquidity constraint.  I agree, but now is not the time for personal opinions or speculation. We need data and analysis from Risk and Strategic Finance (…and it is in the works as far as I understand!) to support an asset allocation strategy and decision. This sort of asset allocation needs to start having a science, analysis and data based grounding - or we will for sure get it wrong as Maker grows further and faster.  I am curious about the proposal from the asset manager but I am also nervous. A treasury portfolio should not, in principle, carry significant credit risk and a cross-over proposal IG-HY to squeeze a few bps of yield I believe doesn’t go in the direction of reserve diversification and yield improvement that an initial treasury portfolio should have.  Here our views on the risk absorption capacity of the balance sheet may divert, but, as above, this is not the time for personal opinions or speculation. It is time for establishing data and analysis on the subject such that the community can make an informed science and data-based decision.  Summarising, I am looking forward to hear more but I would like to understand what is Monetalis position exactly, because I am confused. Is Monetalis?  A structurer, meaning that will provide the structure to Maker to access reputable asset managers remaining agnostic on strategy and partner? An intermediary meaning that will provide structure but also onboard the partners An asset manager itself meaning that it will ask for some level discretion in putting together the strategic and tactical asset allocation based on which the partners will behave   I will make clear shortly what we are - I don’t want people to be confused of course! It is a longer write and so please do give me some days. But, generally speaking, be very wary of trying to put innovative initiatives around MakerDAO into conventional boxes - it won’t work. Remember MakerDAO doesn’t fit any conventional box - and in fact this redesign of the financial system’s value chain boxes is part of its (and DeFi’s you could say) emerging success - it is a new box unto itself.  I believe those jobs to be fairly different. Whether the role of structurer/ intermediary could indeed have significant cross-overs across asset classes, being the discretion mainly at the asset manager level (below), the role of discretionary asset manager has very little scalability (unless Monetalis structure involves 100 people and a battle-tested tech platform) across rates and credit.  So for what we are doing we certainly won’t need that many people for a very long time to come - and most tech we need, for now, is in overabundant Saas supply - but more on that later.  Alternative credit origination, especially, is very time consuming even for a mere aggregator of existing platforms. Differently to what happens for listed securities, platform-originated credit is less standardised, presents spurious data, is very idiosyncratic when it comes to credit policies and quality of execution, and even being an aggregator of existing platforms requires a lot of work and man power. As a benchmark, large alternative credit originating platforms in Europe (I can provide examples if asked) that originate 500m of new loans per year are i) regulated by ECB/ local central banks, ii) have staff ranging between 50 and 100 people, iii) have spent several 10s of MM on proprietary tech platforms, iv) have at least 5 years of history - onboarding an originator typically requires 6 months of work, even before scaling deployment.  Agreed. This is why, as you know from our MIP6 on Monetalis, we are doing senior secured wholesale lending to non-bank lenders focused on unregulated SME lending - and stay far away from platform-originated credit and pure credit origination in general - platform-originated credit has proven reasonably hopeless to manage - many wholesale lenders got in trouble trying to work with these platforms when they were particularly “in vogue” - and pure origination businesses can take a lot of time to scale, require a lot of risky investments, and often doesn’t actually become as successful as one might have hoped. A pure originator business of the kind I think you are alluding to would, usually, have a revenue model focused primarily on origination fees and some equity lending capital exposure margin. Wholesale lenders, like Monetalis, are more akin to an investment manager with revenue solely from % of AuM fees plus profit-share. With Monetalis we’d grow, over 8 to 12 months, to work with a total of around 10 or so lenders to deploy USD 400M - and we’d need about 10 to 15 people over time, to run efficiently and safely the whole operation - a bit larger team than what is market norm, but we want be sure we are equipped to scale further and appropriately support Green Economy underwriting. If wholesale lending required many more people, nobody would be doing this business today in the UK - the maths simply wouldn’t stack up: 1% mgmt fee @ 400M = 4M USD is not going to hire a lot of people and pay for much operations and necessary, substantive, services required (legal, structures, audits, accounting, banking, IT etc). Yes, there is also a profit-sharing component, but that is rarely considered to add much in any cost base evaluation - as it is largely variable. With 10 to 15 employees, this is not the best AuM/person situation - I am not too happy about it I’ll admit. In estimation, by our insider sources, Conister Bank has about 5 people running a growing non-bank SME wholesale lending book of GBP500M+ and Hampshire Trust Bank has a similar GBP200M+ book growing with even fewer staff. Obviously they use their general bank infrastructure for a few things and so you could allocate a few more FTE to their operations, but not many. Anyhow, we accept starting a bit over-staffed compared to industry to ensure we can scale with Maker. As we have so many senior staff with 15y/20y+ experience in industry who knows exactly what is ineffecient in todays wholesale lending processes, we built our own IT helping us to be more efficient (as many of these wholesale lenders are still reasonably paper-based in their processes) and we may invest a bit more in that over this year, but that is only say 500K or a bit more - it is just a wholesale lending onboarding, admin, monitoring and reporting system on AWS. In terms of onboarding lenders, I’d say from first intro meeting to signing facility letter and first dollar out in senior secure loan we are talking about 3 months. Luckily we have a sizable pipeline and several of them are at various stage into this 3 months process so deployment can start very fast.  Looking forward to continue the conversation. As the SES-incubated lead of the Lending Oversight CU I am working closely with RWF on the credit risk and structuring side of the equation, but based on experience and interest (and impact) I remain deeply interested on the evolution of our treasury management strategies as well. content.content: Dear Maker Community, We have reworked the Project Clydesdale MIP substantially to make it more practical and execution focused. We’d like to make a few comments on the ideas behind our rework: As we have worked through Project Clydesdale (and MIP6/MIP68: Monetalis “Green”), it has become clear that we should reasonably be able to implement a satisfactory solution with some speed: Several components are close to finalisation, and the path to finalising missing parts either requires starting the actual execution or specific reasonably well-defined short-lived CU interaction/work/review. To sum up the status quo:     Component Status Quo of Components Principal CU     Structural Almost ready/ready components Trust structure (BVI) Maker off/on-chain Gov concept Banking/Custody/Segregated account Trustee & instruction mechanics  RWF/LTS   Asset Strategy Almost ready/ready offers of strategies:A BlackRock ETF based strategy Baillie Gifford customised bond strategy Goldman Sachs customised strategy  SF   Technical MIP21 based solution CES    Please note that this MIP is not skipping any review steps, but designed for quick collaboration:  Verification required from RWF/LTS on the satisfactory nature of the structure (legal etc) Verification required from SF on the satisfactory nature of the asset strategy We work through the technical implementation as CES directs & coordinates …and it all ends in an executive vote in c4  And, of course, along the way, the Maker community will be kept “in the loop” and potential decisions/compromises debated etc - as always with Maker. I would also like you to clearly understand that before this executive vote in c4, we have to implement everything physically and potentially iterate on it. I.e. we are moving beyond just legal and technical advice and into setting up trust, accounts, trustee services, agreements with asset managers etc, because we can’t establish all the details without this practical chain of execution (for instance: trustee won’t engage before seeing real instructions and final trust agreement, bank won’t truly finalise KYC and fees before seeing trust setup, asset manager won’t finalise and set fees etc before bank and trust in place etc etc). Such that the final executive vote won’t be on a theoretical model or intentions/expectations, but on something that is practically operational. In short, we believe we can implement reasonably fast on a starting USDC reallocation to a bond strategy developed and executed by a top-tier counterparty, in practice. But of course it requires some work and prioritisation from relevant CU’s. We propose, with this MIP, to the MKR holders, that this project is worthy of priority and pace - and set out an attempt at a mechanism that communicates this priority to the community: the non-MIP onboarding blocking mechanism. The non-MIP onboarding block: prioritisation & motivation The non-MIP onboarding block in c1 is a new mechanism. It is an attempt at introducing a strong and reliable decentralised prioritisation mechanism that is intended to ensure that a proposal, ready for fast execution, cannot be easily ignored once the community has approved it with the full authority of the MIP process, as it requires a signal request (c5) process to unblock. It is, of course, important that the community only agree to this type of strong prioritisation for projects that are of substance, well prepared to move through the onboarding steps in the MIP and have the ability to do so at pace (a condition we believe we can satisfy). As the block is certainly not intended to be a lengthy one. If this method proves successful, it could set a strong precedent that projects that are willing and able to do the necessary detailed preparatory work themselves and marshall the resources to quickly more through an onboarding, rather than heavily relying on the CU’s to do all the work, will have a process available to them that ensures all the work they have put in, and resources they are willing to allocated towards this onboarding, are worth it. We believe this would be attractive to a number of larger RWA collateral onboarders/Larger TradFi players, and generally help motivate RWA onboarders to add more investments into creating complete, larger RWA proposals and allocate resources that might allow them to deploy using this process. Taking this path could, eventually, also help alleviate the bottleneck on RWA onboarding by making the process significantly more decentralised, as this process should, as mentioned above, motivate larger RWA onboarding projects to start taking more independent responsibility for their onboarding, rather than expecting others to do the work and carry them through.

content.content: I have been helping Monetalis, as well as some other large and mature RWA projects (that I expect will soon post their own proposals) to design the approach of this MIP. The intention is to use the authority of the MIP process to give voters an option to guarantee that high impact collateral onboardings - that can deploy large debt ceiling and where all the pieces are already in place and just need to be executed - can be prioritized and onboarded instantly after the MIP vote. This should be possible based on the ability of MIPs to dictate the contents of executive votes, by both specifying the exact risk parameters of the collateral to be onboarded, and preventing executive votes of other collateral onboardings that have not been similar specified through a MIP. This way, the game theory means that everyone involved will work together to perform the onboardings even if their primary objective is to onboard something else, since finishing the onboarding of the collateral that has been prioritized at the MIP level opens up for the onboarding of other things. I think Robert makes some good points about the language here, though. It actually isn’t 100% clear that this is guaranteed to supersede all other collateral onboardings, and by not recognising the established collateral onboarding process risks damaging it. I will suggest some edits that would help provide stronger guarantees. A crucial requirement is that the voters are careful to set the precedent that this type of MIP can only be approved for projects that do in fact have a significant impact with high debt ceiling and guaranteed demand for credit that will go towards quality collateral, and on top of that have an airtight legal structure that make it maximally secure to transfer large amounts of Dai into it, while following MIP21 on the technical which is a simple implementation that has already been proven to work, meaning it can be directly copied with no R&D requirements. It should only be used carefully, since misuse could result in clogging up the entire collateral onboarding process and forcing the community to deal with a cancellation, but the key is then to make sure that anyone that ends up having to be cancelled will have their reputation ruined and should never expect to be able to onboard collateral again

content.content: Hi @rune thank you for this clarification. I have a question. Given that you’re suggesting this type of MIPs are presented through this channel due to their high impact and ready-to-go form, has this ready-to-go form been assessed or reviewed by anyone else that doesn’t represent the applicant? Since the beginning of my involvement as prospective facilitator of a Lending Oversight core unit, I have been trying to introduce in the DAO the importance of proper checks and balances. I can’t speak for the technical requirements that @monkey.irish’s team would address, but on the legal structure, has @christiancdpetersen (as prospective facilitator of a LTS core unit and current support for the DAO) or any other independent legal advisor reviewed the structure and offered an official legal opinion on its merits? Also, to @monkey.irish point, I’m uncertain about the applicability of the self-contained prioritisation against any other MIP type. Would that mean that the community is forced to ultimately find an implementation solution putting otherwise the protocol in a de facto stalling situation for new improvements? Doesn’t this transform the MIP65 into a gatekeeper of the rest of the development flow, basically stripping out from the appointed CUs a big part of their mandate when it comes to recommending implementation only if the technical, risk, and legal conditions arise? More practically, a great idea that receives a favourable vote might ultimately turn impractical for mere technical yet very important reasons. What would happen in this case? I have no doubts on the professional stance of the Monetalis team or its shareholders. The reasons I am addressing this, is that we believe that if a MIP is presented for urgent and immediate implementation, its merits and especially structural appropriateness should be assessed by a legally bound third party or, ideally, the CUs that have been voted for this within the DAO. If a counterweight is not present, it feels that those types of MIPs are too similar to the Fast-Track process that was voted down recently through a Signal. Apologies if I’m missing something, I am sure Governance and others will be able to clarify the boundaries of those MIPs.

content.content: luca_pro:  More practically, a great idea that receives a favourable vote might ultimately turn impractical for mere technical yet very important reasons. What would happen in this case?   This is a key point, and basically what I tried to explain here.  It should only be used carefully, since misuse could result in clogging up the entire collateral onboarding process and forcing the community to deal with a cancellation, but the key is then to make sure that anyone that ends up having to be cancelled will have their reputation ruined and should never expect to be able to onboard collateral again  The MIP itself has a check (in c2 under verification) that would in this case practically require Christian (through Will as the facilitator) to verify that the actual implemented structure indeed provides the protections that it should. This can only be truly done after the structures are in place - it’s not enough to review the plan and the intended structure, because you can never be sure what is actually created is what was claimed or planned before the fact. So Monetalis have in advance checked with Christian and others that the structure they plan to put in place are appropriate. Monetalis then makes the proposal, and if they get the go ahead signal, that would enable them to pull the trigger and pay the expenses of setting up the structures. Then the structures would be set up and the final verification of the de facto structure can be performed. If the proposer didn’t check with professionals and/or mandated actors beforehand, or if they try to implement something different from what they promise to, then the MIP just breaks the collateral onboarding process, and must be manually cancelled through a signal request - which is going to ruin the reputation and political capital of the proposer. For an arranger such as Monetalis that is a death sentence and a risk they are certain to do everything possible to avoid. There’s one more crucial element that I realize we need to add, which is the possibility of the proposer to unilaterally and instantly cancel the onboarding, which would be the only way for them to salvage their reputation if it turns out an onboarding wasn’t actually “ready to go” after all, but it was due to an honest mistake. The goal is that we use game theory to ensure only actual high quality proposal would ever dare to risk making a MIP-level onboarding, so it becomes a filter that ensures that it will always be worth it for the community to deeply scrutinize collateral onboarding proposals that are made in the form of a self contained MIP. The recent HVB proposal arranged by RWA co is another example of a very high value collateral onboarding proposal that IMO also should be done with a MIP level onboarding, IMO, without being an expert, it is simply too valuable to not provide a guarantee directly from maker governance that it will be swiftly onboarded if it is verified. that all the structures and legal guarantees have been put in place, and verified that the structure is restricted to only acquire assets at the level of quality Maker demands.

content.content: Hi Allan In general I am a fan of proposals that aim to address the large amount of USDC in the system while pursuing added revenue for the Maker Protocol. I do have one important question though: How do you intend to deal with an unplanned Emergency Shutdown scenario? If you are not familiar with the mechanics, Maker Governance can trigger Emergency Shutdown which will settle the protocol e.g. in case there is a bug or governance attack. You can read more about it here and here. The TL;DR is that the protocol will automatically settle all vaults and Dai tokens will become redeemable for a relative share of the underlying collateral in the system. Using today’s data, that would mean that each Dai would be redeemable for 54 cents worth of USDC, 22 cents worth of ETH, 6 cents of WBTC and etc. as illustrated below. (See daistats for a real time distribution).  Since this MIP proposes using MIP21 for the technical solution the representation of collateral onchain is a “dummy” RWA token that in itself does not have any market value and from a technical point of view does not constitute any claim on the underlying collateral which is offchain in the real world. To illustrate an example, if there is a total Dai supply of 10 billion, and this MIP65 vault has generated 500 M Dai (maxed out the proposed debt ceiling, accounting for 5 % of total supply). If emergency shutdown is triggered, this means that 5 % (5 cent) of the value of each Dai will be attributed to this RWA token, and will be distributed to Dai redeemers accordingly. So Dai holders upon redemption will now be given a bunch of RWA tokens, however the problem is that these tokens in itself do not constitute any claim on the underlying real world assets, and as such does not have an organic market value, as you cannot sell it off in any exchange such as Uniswap. So my question is, how will Dai holders be made whole in such a scenario? Will you be committed to buy back the RWA tokens from Dai redeemers? If there is no path to redeem or sell off the RWA tokens in case of emergency shutdown it would mean a 5 % value haircut for all Dai holders after ES, meaning that Dai would actually be valued at 0.95 USD in the example above, rather than 1.00 USD, as they would not be able to sell off the redeemed RWA tokens in the market. In all fairness this is an issue that exists with existing RWA vaults as well, however the magnitude of the proposed debt ceiling for this vault increases the problem almost 10-fold, where today the max RWA exposure would be at 59M which today would mean about 0.6 % of each Dai being backed by RWA vs potentially 5 %. CES have done some preliminary work on designing a solution that would deal with this issue by continuing MIP21-type RWA loans after emergency shutdown and facilitate gradual payback to holders of the RWA tokens, however from an implementation standpoint it is still early. Whatever the process might be, I think the DAO should have a well defined plan upfront for such a scenario.

content.content: I can’t speak for Monetalis, but for other current and proposed MIP21 Vaults it’s actually quite a simple solution. In the event of an emergency shutdown, the Trustee is instructed to convert the USD back to an alternative stablecoin (e.g. USDC) and to repay Dai holders with that token. So it effectively maintains its status as a claim on dollars.

content.content: I think the basic approach of using USDC or similar to manually, through a legal process, repay each dai holder (with dai already in claim mode) that comes to settle their collateral, works pretty well. There might be some KYC issues but in practice this just means that large entities that are able to pass strict KYC will buy up all the dai and then deal with the settlement. I also have some old designs for more advanced and smoother solutions that could be used in the long run, the most interesting being that RWA vaults simply “switch recognition” to a new Maker deployment and the Dai from that deployment is then eligible to claim by dai holders with their dai in claim mode. IMO the most important thing is that the solution must be entirely on the legal side. There is nothing to gain from adding more complexity on the technical side, because the ability to access the assets is fundamentally driven by a legal structure and will only work if it’s properly enforced through legal means.

content.content: Hi @lollike , Monetalis intended structure works similarly to what @g_dip and @rune suggest (i.e. Maker instruction to trustee to signal and ensure irrevocable full or partial liquidation immediately). Just to put some more colour on this: the bond strategies we are looking at are tasked to liquidate to cash very fast, and then exchange to USDC or other relevant stablecoin in case of the emergency shutdown you mention - or directly to DAI in case the liquidation request is made for the purpose of providing liquidity in response to a DAI crisis. We are currently stress testing liquidation patterns for market conditions and price consequences for various bond strategies so we can understand the dynamics hereof. As an example here’s a quote from a recent report on a customized bond strategy for Maker from one of the asset managers we are working with (and this is not the ETF-based strategy or the most liquid of the strategies we are testing out - but this one captured some reasonable yield and remained within investment grade and short term duration constraints, and so we wanted to understand its liquidity pattern):  …we typically test our credit portfolios assuming 40% market capture with a price tolerance of no more than 1% above current mid-bid spreads. On this basis 99% of a $500m portfolio could be liquidated within a day in current market conditions. If we tighten the price impact to 0.25% then 78% could be liquidated within a day and 90% within 3 days…  On top of all this we are also looking to potentially setup a credit line (secured on the portfolio) that would allow us to get cash immediately without disturbing the portfolio or, at least, give the portfolio time to liquidate orderly (markets can dry entirely out in times of broad financial crisis) More on this to very soon. As you can imagine, ultimately one needs to come down on some appropriate combination of liquidity pattern/underlying risk/mark-to-market volatility/yield/etc that works for Maker.

content.content: Hi @monkey.irish This MIP approves a process to get a sizable priority collateral (it starts addressing the issue of USDC exposure in practice) onboarded at pace, and sets out a clear process for doing so. The process involves a set of verification requirements and a process “hand-brake” (signal) that can be pulled at any time - before the onboarding is up for a final executive vote. All details, as a result of the verification processes, will be known and discussed before this final executive vote. We believe we can get this onboarding done fast - elements not complete yet require moving into the practical implementation to settle, which we know we can do at pace. I am entirely committed to using the unilateral withdrawal mechanism in this MIP, in the unlikely and unexpected event that something slows down the verification and onboarding process. If we cannot get the promised pace into this onboarding, I will withdraw it immediately. As such, this MIP will neither lead to an inappropriate collateral being onboarded nor clog up the onboarding process. It has checks and triggers in it to ensure this doesn’t happen. Instead it should lead to an appropriate, priority collateral being onboarded quickly. I also hope that learnings from this onboarding could inform the process and prioritisation mechanism changes that I know CES is working on - work we absolutely support.

content.content: Wouldn’t the easiest way just be to put into a legal agreement that the borrower is committed to buy back any fraction of RWA tokens, using a simple order book exchange like OasisDEX? In standard MIP21, there’s a singular RWA token (RWA-00X), which in this case would be valued at 500 M. In case of ES, Monetalis could then set up a buy order for the entire supply (1 RWA token) at 500 M USDC, that would allow users to redeem their tokens. Another approach I’ve been thinking about is simply turning the RWA tokens into a bond like instrument post ES. This would mean that we could continue the loan agreement, but that the repayment of Dai would happen to another module that would allow RWA token holders to redeem at a maturity date for the principal + yield. In case there was a redeployment of the Maker Protocol, those yield generating tokens could be onboarded as collateral with a corresponding stability fee, meaning that the yield would then go to a new surplus buffer instead, effectively meaning the loan was migrated to the new system. I think in the case of ES it would actually be good to have a mechanism to continue the loans because in that scenario having a potential steady income for the DAO would be beneficial in ensuring its continued operations. I agree that it should be fairly simple to do to setup a process, I just think it would be good to establish this concrete process upfront of how a Dai holder would redeem their tokens, because depending on the process there are different operational requirements and risks. If the process does indeed require KYC it would be good to understand the process and have an idea of the types of market participatents, to understand if the process will be competitive and efficient. E.g. in the extreme case that only a singular actor goes through the KYC process for a specific underlying asset (either they are the only one eligible, or the only one that bothers), they would have a monopoly on the market for redeeming RWA tokens and can dictate the price, which would lead to a large haircut. To me this is also a broader discussion of the sunk costs of preparing for Emergency Shutdown. This is something that engineers spend a lot of time on, yet it is arguable how confident we are that this mechanism will work as intended in practice, as bugs are still being discovered, and as the system increases in complexity and becomes more intertwined with other protocols is very hard to properly simulate. However if we do not design for it, we are also basically abandoning the function. So either we prepare for ES properly from both a technical and operational POV so we know it’s a viable mechanic, or we effectively abandon it. I’m not really for or against either option, but we shouldn’t keep investing in something unless we know it is going to work.

content.content: I would like to thank @Allan_Pedersen and the Monetalis team for this proposal. I am writing the following as prospective facilitator of the Lending Oversight Core Unit, consistent with the mandate to act protecting good internal checks and balances, and as a second internal line of defence for what concerns structured lending risk, in it’s wide sense.  On the Proposal’s Intentions As I have discussed previously, and consistent with the view expressed by @SebVentures above, I believe there is great merit in what Clydesdale’s intends to achieve. The deployment of part of the USDC treasury we have is a crucial problem that we need to address in the immediate future, as there are many ways to improve its counterparty risk profile while optimising the deriving yield. Some of the Core Units (Growth, RWF, Strategic Finance, incubated LTS and LOVE, and others) have been facilitating conversations with reputable asset managers that are expressing their desire to explore potential collaborations with the protocol for this reason, but a multiple track where several proponents are exploring potential solutions is advisable. For this reason, I endorse personally Allan’s efforts. In its ideal form the proposal should have minimum embedded credit risk and therefore should fall more within the domain of @strat-fin-core-unit rather than @Real-World-Finance, with liquidity being the overarching concern. I am saying in its ideal form, because it isn’t yet clear what will be the mandate in its detail; for this reason I would envisage both @Aes and @williamr to engage with Monetalis and team to define a detailed mandate ahead of implementation.  On Monetalis as the Proponent Monetalis has proven to be very entrepreneurial in their intentions, fast to respond to the challenges, and very close to the community. This is of great value. Currently, Monetalis has two MIPs outstanding, MIP65 on liquid bonds (this MIP) and MIP68 on a credit vault (here). Both initiatives are extremely new and will have significant challenges. Although I understand from the Monetalis’ team that both will have significant structuring challenges, I am against endorsing simultaneously two very different strategies to be run by the same intermediary and both as a first mandate, and I would be significantly more comfortable with Monetalis deciding which one to prioritise first I will try to describe my concerns:  The role of lender and liquid asset allocator are very different and difficult to implement in sync. There are two alternative mental models we could see Monetalis through, the 1st one is considering Monetalis as a full fledged asset management, that underwrites risk internally and takes directional execution on those risks (the Asset Manager model), the 2nd one is considering Monetalis as an outsourced investment office or intermediary working with other asset managers (the Asset Allocator model). In case Monetalis sees itself as an Asset Manager, I believe that it is premature for a lender or investor like MakerDAO to endorse two very distinctive strategies simultaneously for a start-up fund, premature and with little precedent in the market at this size. In the case instead Monetalis sees itself as an Asset Allocator, MakerDAO should receive significant more colour about what underlying investment managers Monetalis intends to engage, their track record, and what is the underlying strategy, before approval Monetalis’ team is a new team, with limited capacity and unproven track record - it would be advisable for the team to focus on the execution of one initiative and prove itself on one before trying to tackle (very) different things at the same time Monetalis’ team is a small team, without evident specialised knowledge for both initiatives  It is my opinion that Monetalis’ impact for the community would be higher and better fitting with its core skills with Clydesdale rather than Vault v2, but it is not for me to say. As a prospective control group within MakerDAO, however, I would suggest MKR token holders to think carefully whether to endorse Monetalis simultaneously on two very challenging, and very different, proposals.  On the Proposal’s Intended Process I won’t repeat @monkey.irish’s words here too much, but I will reiterate that the ad hoc nature of this (and other) MIP is concerning on a process perspective for the protocol. Namely:  The current proposal does not have the required details on strategy and execution partners for the community to have a fully informed decision that leads to immediate implementation The intention not to follow the Collateral Onboarding Process, with the Domain Teams assessing all questions before onboarding, raises several additional risks that aren’t necessary The ad hoc prioritisation demanded by the current MIP takes away from the Domain Teams one of their current abilities, which is to prioritise all existing proposals based on their knowledge and the mandate they have been empowered with by the community, and without sufficient a priori information; this has the risk of reducing over the medium term the ability of the protocol to evolve in the interest of the “first come first served” MIP proponent, and in addition to push every counterparty to unilaterally define the criticality of their MIP disregarding the collateral onboarding process and the structured approach that the Domain Teams are maintaining and evolving  For this reason, I feel deeply uncomfortable to endorse a MIP that intends to bypass any structured process in favour of an ad hoc one. We understand that the current MIP process is imperfect, but I would advise Monetalis to converge back towards the standard MIP process and help simultaneously the Domain Teams to improve this process for the future. Ad hoc solutions might seem efficient in the short term, but their cost in the medium one cannot be underestimated. Regards, Luca

content.content: About the Quality of Monetalis I’m not going to add more to the quality of this proposal, mainly because people with much more expertise have already.  Interacting with Maker Governance  Monetalis’ Exchange with Governance  MIP6  Speedy-boarding attempt (arguably, not theirs) War Bonds for Ukraine MIP65 MIP68   On-chain Equivalent? A Team launches a coin. They propose it through a MIP6. @Risk-Core-Unit / @Protocol-Engineering / @Oracles-Core-Unit tell the community that we should focus on other deals. A Team then proposes a standalone MIP to get onboarded (?). Passing this MIP is telling the aforementioned teams .  On the Importance of Frameworks  Is MIP6 not enough? We have frameworks for a reason. If MIP6 is not sufficient, we should fix it. (Probably @collateral-core-unit has a thousand ideas for this).  The need for prioritization We also need to be clear on how to prioritize (and how to communicate it with our partners and communities). Maker should onboard collateral types based on a lot of different factors, but hopefully, the amount of MIPs/forum posts written by the team is not a decisive factor.  Where’s the referee? Some people have approached me saying that @GovAlpha-Core-Unit should shield governance from this type of proposal. I think that refereeing is quite hard, and we don’t want to “censor” good projects or ideas.  This MIP in Particular The two points below are quite important to me. The @MIP-Editors might disagree, but I’m having a hard time understanding what governance is voting on exactly. We will have some interesting discussions regarding the implementation of this MIP as is.  The Trojan Horse Attribute A proposal with prioritization within? That’s quite the novelty. Ideally, we would vote on proposals and priorities separately.  Self-contained MIP? This MIP does not contain enough information to be self-contained.  Unhappy Path What happens if any of the Maker checks fail?  Conclusion Even if (big if) this was the best collateral type in the world, the precedent for this MIP passing would be quite bad, from a governance perspective.

content.content: IMO it is extremely important context to add that the only example of a proper RWA deal that has EVER been done in Maker was by 6s Capital, following a process similar to this with MIP21 and MIP13c3-SP4. We are talking about using the Maker Improvement Proposal process here. It’s the undisputed fundamental process of Maker Governance. I don’t think it is reasonable to characterise it as “ad hoc”, or dismiss it based on appeal to bureaucracy, when it clearly follows the only example that exists in the category of what it’s trying to do, using the one fundamental, rock solid process that we have available.  My main concern against backing this proposal goes to preserving Core Unit autonomy. This proposal makes very specific instructions on how to proceed in the event of a positive vote, with limited possibility of Core Units influence or discretion. While I do see the wish for an expedited process it does set a precedent for future on-boarding applications.  This proposal does give Core Units full autonomy, they have the complete unilateral ability to accept or reject the proposal based on whether it fulfils the very straight forward requirements that spelled out, that provide full protections for MKR holders interests. This is very clearly spelled out in the components of the MIP. Btw, there are multiple other major RWA deals considering using this approach to attempt an onboarding. Why? Because there currently exists no process that can be trusted to actually work or provide any kind of certainty around timeframe, which makes it unfeasible. We cannot expect businesses to work with us based on some inner passion or charity that makes them keep getting up again no matter how many bureaucratic curveballs they get. We are no longer some hobby project, we are the scale of billions and that requires working with real businesses that need to be able to reasonably estimate that they will get a positive expected value out of the time, energy and costs of trying to interact with Maker. Btw I realize now that I removed the earlier post where i originally put this disclaimer: it’s important to note that I am an investor in Monetalis and have a financial interest in this proposal passing(not that it bears any weight against my MKR holdings). At the same time, I never vote on proposals and never influence the votes of delegates (in terms of reallocating votes based on specific voting behaviour). However, the other projects I am supporting with getting their deals onboarded using the MIP process are being done purely in my interest as an MKR holder that wants to see something finally getting done.

content.content: @blimpa  - could you please move this MIP into formal submission. Thanks!

I’ll start by saying I am in support of trying something like this out starting at a small scale and growing in a safe way (under the system surplus until legal recourse is fully sorted). That being said, I object strongly to the language in this MIP. This paragraph in particular:  To ensure the onboarding occurs as fast as is reasonable, and isn’t unnecessarily delayed, no other collateral onboardings with debt-ceiling below DAI 100M can occur, unless those collateral onboardings also have been directly and specifically authorised through a self-contained, stand-alone, numbered MIP similar to this.  If passed, this would effectively block D3Ms, multi-chain liquidity strategies, MCD deployments on other chains, wormhole, etc. All of which are being worked on largely in parallel. I can appreciate some things can appear to be moving slowly from the outside, but from what I’ve seen the teams are moving as fast as possible on multiple fronts. I’ve seen the DAO grow and professionalize over the past year, and I believe we are starting to hit our stride. Cross team communication and transparency have sometimes been lacking (growing pains of a flat structure), but we are identifying and correcting the problems. Even just reading this discussion I can see that the process for getting something onboarded is not clear. CUs are working to fix this. As a mandated actor, I can say that from my experience we are actively working to grow the yield-bearing DAI supply as fast as possible. From what I can see nobody is stone-walling, everyone is acting in good faith and we are largely aligned on the same goals. This is human nature sometimes when you don’t have full view into the decision making process to assume bad faith. We must resist this impulse as much as possible especially during this rapid growth phase. The Core Units were elected to do a job, and if you don’t trust our judgement you should vote us out. Forcing through a MIP from an outside party which ties our hands on using best judgement is a huge mistake, and I would like to see a MIP soon that prevents this sort of forced language as it will likely be abused in the future.

content.content: I think it’s an important point that there are many situations where experimentation with small scale debt ceilings are critical for the development of new features, such as Maker Wormhole, and that currently these would in theory be affected by the prioritization block described in this MIP. But on the other hand, when new features are introduced to the protocol, that is typically done through a full MIP that clearly specifies the upgrade and expansion of the protocol. As long as that precedent continues to be followed then all it would require to overcome this issue is that the feature upgrade MIP specifies that it has a collateral onboarding component to it (if creating a vault type is necessary for launching the feature). This would clearly make a it qualify as a collateral onboarding that has “been directly and specifically authorised through a self-contained, stand-alone, numbered MIP” and become able to circumvent the block on sub-100M collateral onboardings. Some early significant examples of “feature upgrade MIPs”: MIP25: Flash Mint Module MIP27: Debt Ceiling Instant Access Module MIP29: Peg Stability Module MIP30: Farmable cUSDC Adapter (CropJoin) IMO the precedent set by these feature MIPs is very beneficial to the protocol since it helps make it very clear when the scope and complexity of the protocol is expanded, so I wouldn’t think it is a problem that collateral onboarding of large and significant collateral types makes it harder to break with this precedent. It’s important to point out that arguably at least the Protocol Engineering Core Units do have a specific authorization to technically make upgrades or changes to the protocol based on language in MIP41c2: Facilitator Governance Powers  Facilitators have the power to propose weekly Executive Votes (defined in MIP16) related to their Core Units.  However, in practice even after receiving this power in MIP41 the precedent of using the full MIP process for large scale protocol upgrades has still been followed, with examples such as: MIP45: Liquidations 2.0 - Liquidation System Redesign MIP50: Direct Deposit Module MIP69: L2 to L1 Fast Withdrawals IMO the same general logic goes for e.g. the SocGen onboarding as Nadia points out - it’s a new and ambitious type of collateral onboarding, and such onboardings have a similar existing precedent of making sure that such expansions of the collateral type implementations are approved through the full MIP process. some examples of “new type of collateral onboarding” MIPs, such as MIP21: Real World Assets - Off-Chain Asset Backed Lender MIP22: Centrifuge Direct Liquidation Module The PSM and D3M MIPs from above are some other examples One thing I just want to make sure is also clear is that the prioritization blocks that have been posted so far are limited to blocking collateral onboarding of a scale of less than 100 million. This means Core Units would still be able to freely use their Facilitator governance privilege to do large scale collateral onboardings of more than 100 million, which means there’s no possibility that large and significant deals, that can be done faster than the MIPs process would allow, would be deprioritized because of an existing self-contained collateral onboarding MIP. I think if there are still issues beyond this, then it would be important to address them as much as possible in current MIPs in RFC, or any future MIPs that want to use a prioritization enforcement component. As for MIP65, it’s already in formal submission so Allan wouldn’t be able to make changes to it at this stage. But Allan already pledged to use the unilateral withdrawal mechanism if any sort of delay occurs, so it should be expected that if this MIP goes through it will no matter what result in a very swift removal of the non-MIP small collateral onboarding block. And overall we are talking about a single proposal to finally, finally, finally get something done by removing and activating 500 million of the 6 billion USDC we have sitting around following best practice that we know is safe from a legal, risk and liquidity perspective and in a manner that is fully guided and verified by the relevant mandated actors including Christian from RWF and the Strategic Finance Core Unit. Even if bureaucratically it isn’t absolutely perfect I just don’t see why that matters when it gets something so worthwhile done. The perfect bureaucracy can come later, but it isn’t here yet, and until it’s here it just makes no sense to delay or shut down progress.

content.content: So it sounds like the option 1 is to vote this in and get this onboarded as quickly as possible and option 2 is vote it down and force it to start over without the language that it should be prioritized.  This would restart the onboarding process and the mandatory waiting periods. From my uninformed and outside perspective, this all just sounds like a power struggle.  Monetalis wants some certainty that this onboarding will be taken seriously and worked on and core units don’t want to be forced into prioritizing this through the proposal (even if it is a priority).  You could say there’s a little bit of trust lacking on both sides. The answer is probably no but is there any way for a third option to make amendments without restarting the waiting periods?  Informally agree to prioritize this MIP but allow for work to continue where it needs to continue.  Agree to a reasonable time frame for assessments and polls.  Agree that this MIP is not precedent setting since changes to the process are being made anyway.  Hopefully, future proposals won’t feel the need to put this clause in because the priority process is clarified and improved. Anyway, I agree that delegates should just speak up on their stance so we don’t waste time.  If it’s a big enough priority, I think it’s okay to vote just approve it and caveat your vote with your disagreement to the clause in question.  Rejecting it over something like this sends a message too.  Maybe that’s the message you want.  Delays to obviously beneficial proposals and ideas are easier to stomach for those who are still getting paid but it’s definitely frustrating for the average mkr holder.
