content.content: Can this priority paragraph be overridden by a new majority vote later? It is controversial but is not clear it offers actual guarantee Thank you

Hello from GovAlpha  We wanted to first confirm that this MIP is valid for submission and will be proceeding to a Ratification Poll on Monday. Additionally, we felt it would be good to highlight what this proposal asks of specific Core Units, as well as explain how we would be mandated to respond if this MIP passed. This will hopefully clear up any lingering confusion for Core Units and others observing this thread. Finally, just to clairify we will not be allowing changes to this MIP after the frozen period. If @Allan_Pedersen wishes to withdraw the formal submission to make changes before the May cycle that is alright, but in order for it to be considered on Monday, it must do so in its current form (like all other MIPs entering the April cycle). The following instructions and mandates would result if this proposal passes:  Core Unit Instructions @Real-World-Finance, @luca_pro (LOVE incubation), and @christiancdpetersen (LTS incubation) are instructed to “provide a Verification of the legal and governance structure appropriateness for holding a large amount of low risk real world asset collateral for Maker” via a forum post. @strat-fin-core-unit are instructed to “provide a Verification of the Asset Purchase and Allocation Restriction ensuring that only execution of bond strategies appropriate to use as large scale liquid RWA collateral can be acquired with assets provided to the legal structure by Maker” via a forum post. @collateral-core-unit (with the support of @Protocol-Engineering (and other relevant supporting CUs) are instructed to “deploy smart contracts that hard code the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure specified in MIP65c2, and follow the MIP21 framework.” Note that:     Allan_Pedersen:  These smart contracts must only allow for the generation of Dai through a vault that is sent to the ETH address of the legal structure as its ultimate destination, and it must not be technically possible to send the Dai elsewhere, in accordance with MIP21. There must also not be any additional technical features or complexity that goes beyond the minimum necessary smart contracts and dummy constructs to enable the generation of Dai and its transfer to the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure. The ability to initiate the generation of Dai from the vault and trigger their transfer to the ETH Address emitted by the legal structure is given to an Ethereum address controlled by Monetalis. This address must have no ability to access the funds    GovAlpha Resulting Mandates The most relevant passage here is:     Allan_Pedersen:  To ensure the onboarding occurs as fast as is reasonable, and isn’t unnecessarily delayed, no other collateral onboardings with debt-ceiling below DAI 100M can occur, unless those collateral onboardings also have been directly and specifically authorised through a self-contained, stand-alone, numbered MIP similar to this.   We find this wording to be unambiguous, it clearly instructs GovAlpha not to put any new collateral onboarding through an executive vote unless:  The initial Debt Ceiling is at or above 100 million DAI OR The collateral onboarding in question is the result of a stand-alone MIP.  This would exclude MIP6 Collateral Onboarding Applications. It would also exclude D3M implementations that are not approved through their own MIP process (meaning that MIP50: DAI Direct Deposit Module does not pave the way for other specific D3M integrations). Additionally, while the Wormhole implementation would not be excluded (it is a bridge for DAI, and doesn’t seem to match the intent of this MIP), any new collaterals occuring on L2s would be subject to the restrictions of the MIP.  Potential Governance Complications As we have already seen other proposals utilize the same prioritization language, there can be a rather obvious conflict if a future proposal(s) seek to exclude/gain priority over this one before it can be implemented. In this event, governance would essentially be locked until an amendment, un-blocking" signal, or some other superseding governance imperatives were passed by MKR holders. There may also be some debate on what counts as collateral onboarding as defined by this MIP. While items like D3M have caused some confusion in the onboarding process (they are both implementing a collateral and a new technical integration with another service or platform), it should generally be understood that if this MIP passes Governance should not be able to vote on new credit facilities unless the above exceptions are present.  Questions and Comments GovAlpha has had a busy couple of weeks responding to inquiries about the language in this MIP and found making a public post such as this one would be the best course of action. As always, follow-up here is encouraged and we will continue our best efforts to respond to inquiries about the governance nature of new proposals. Edit: some of the @Recognized-Delegates have been asking about this as well, thanks to Pablo for suggesting to add the tag

content.content: Allan_Pedersen:  Barbell strategy best to accomplish liquidity/security/yield in today’s market (late credit cycle) Consistently the suggestion is that to accomplish both yield and liquidity, there needs to be a component that is (fx government bonds) secure, interest-rate sensitive and liquid, but returning close to no yield at this moment - and then another part of the portfolio that is focused on yield in the longer-term (fx corporate bonds of investment grade). Such a strategy may include a diversification mix of maturities, borrower types, geography, theme focus and investment ratings. We are pursuing further evidence of this strategy’s appropriateness. Just for illustration of a Barbell strategy see this picture:   With how new this whole thing is i would suggest not being overly worried with high returns at this stage. I think the priority here should be getting all of the legal hurdles out of the way and start to prove that this trust you are creating can ACTUALLY BE TRUSTED. That being the case I would suggest sticking to the lowest risk option for now, and not be overly concerned with sharpe ratios or even total returns. You guys can optimize returns later if you pull this off without losing people billions.

content.content: hexonaut:  do not trust the Core Units to add this or perhaps want to bypass due diligence.   At first I was pretty shocked by the united front from the core units in this thread, but after taking a step back I’ve been able to look at the situation with fresh eyes. In light of the strong reaction I can understand how this was perceived badly, and because of the lack of warning and the approach of applying all the critical details as an edit in at the last second I understand why that triggered the emotional and personal reactions we’ve seen. I can understand that it felt kind of like an attack, and as a result there’s an instinctual response of lashing back, especially when its coming from allan but with me clearly lurking on the sidelines. In hindsight I should have spent a lot more time talking to people behind the scenes, trying to prepare people for this and ensure it didnt result in this kind of negative first impression. But hope you can trust me that I simply approached this from a DAO, decentralization and game theoretic perspective, and simply misjudged to what degree we are starting to mature past the stage where behind the scenes conversations are important before engaging publicly on something new and ambitious. It’s not about trust in any individual, it was simply a question of providing Allan and others the best advice on how to make sure these large, potentially important and lucrative deals can most directly deal with the daunting task of attempting a collateral onboarding, knowing how many things have already gotten stuck over the years. I believe in this approach because it provides clarity, transparency and proves we can get things done. The prioritization enforcement means that for the first time ever, the DAO will be in a situation where it can make a decision with a very high level of clarity about the results. Without such a things will slow down significantly, not just on the core unit side but on both ends. It’s like the prisoners dillema - if there’s nothing pushing core units to prioritize this, as a result there would be a lot of hesitation on the monetalis side to take the risk on paying the necessary expenses to get it to a point where it can fully verified. This hesitation would in turn make core units further deprioritize it etc. Things would happen much slower, and maybe could completely stall if the right human interactions and relationships aren’t in place to drive it and try to push it forward. On the other hand, with a clear prioritization that actually can be counted on, both sides can move in tandem, coordinate and get it done and dealt with and out the door, so Maker can get rid of USDC as quickly as possible, and the core units can move on to the next deal. I really hope that people can step back from this and take a look at this proposal objectively and see it for what it is - a vote that will allow us to decisively onboard 500 million of no-brainer collateral and finally put a dent in the USDC. IMO if you read the language carefully there should be no question about the due diligence embedded in this proposal. This proposal provides much stronger and better due diligence compared to the standard MIP6 process, which calls for a (paraphrased) “risk assessment, oracle assessment, and smart contracts assessment” which are not really that relevant for an RWA onboarding. Meanwhile this proposal explicitly embeds an assessment of the legal structure, and unambiguously requires a full verification, that the protections that are clearly spelled out in the MIP, are in place in the actual de facto implemented legal structure. Without such a verification no there’s no possibility of a debt ceiling being implemented.  Legal structure and governance appropriateness Verification The Real World Finance Facilitator and the “in SES incubation” Facilitator of Legal and Transactions Services must, through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the legal and governance structure appropriateness for holding a large amount of low risk real world asset collateral for Maker.  And it provides a liquidity assessment with similar levels of protections. The de facto implemented legal mechanism that regulates what assets the trust can purchase needs to be assessed and verified to be appropriate from a liquidity perspective for use as large scale liquid Maker collateral, by the Strategic Finance Core Unit who have Asset-Liability Management as one of their responsibilites.  Asset Purchase and Allocation Restriction Verification The Strategic Finance Facilitator must, also through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the Asset Purchase and Allocation Restriction ensuring that only execution of bond strategies appropriate to use as large scale liquid RWA collateral can be acquired with assets provided to the legal structure by Maker.  And again, the Core Units have FULL AUTONOMY to make these assessments and use their professional expertise and judgement to decide whether the collateral onboarding fulfills the strict conditions mentioned above, and as a result should go through or not. Even if this MIP is voted through, they have full autonomy to block it.  these Verifications are, of course, voluntary in nature. Should one such Verification not be forthcoming, for whatever reason, this MIP will not move forward in the collateral onboarding process to eventually fulfil the conditions of MIP65c4 (executive vote and block removal) and the Maker Community can use MIP65c5 (cancellation procedure) to remove the onboarding block, or Monetalis can use MIP65c6 to unilaterally withdraw the Collateral Onboarding and remove the non-MIP Collateral Onboarding block.  Finally there’s the unilateral withdrawal which ensures that in practice, if any kind of issue should arise then the collateral onboarding will immediately be withdrawn and the prioritization enforcement block will be removed instantaneously.  MIP65c6: Unilateral Instant Collateral Onboarding withdrawal   After this MIP has been approved, Monetalis can at any time through a public forum post, unilaterally withdraw the Collateral Onboarding application. This nullifies all aspects of MIP65c1, MIP65c2, MIP65c3 and MIP65c4, and instantly removes the Collateral Onboarding block specified MIP65c1, and formally removes MIP65 from the Collateral Onboarding process.   This option allows the proposer to prevent their reputation from being damaged by forcing the community to spend time and energy on performing a MIP65c5 cancellation procedure, if some unforeseen issue should arise after the approval of the MIP.  and Allan’s quote from later in the post:  I am entirely committed to using the unilateral withdrawal mechanism in this MIP, in the unlikely and unexpected event that something slows down the verification and onboarding process. If we cannot get the promised pace into this onboarding, I will withdraw it immediately.  The game theory of why this is guaranteed to happen since allan will need to do it to protect his reputation should be quite clear.  In either case the language sets a terrible precedent.  IMO this really depends on the context of this united front of pushback from the core units, and the answer to this following question: Assuming that MIP65 is approved end of April and fully executed over the course of May, what exactly are the collateral onboarding(s) that are  less than 100 million debt ceiling guaranteed to get fully finalized and executed in May provide superior value to the community compared to this deal  (a side question is also why didn’t we know about such a rock solid plan and timeline already and why wasnt that the main argument from the start) Now, if such a situation exists, where there is a clearly superior choice being prepared by the Core Units to be executed through Facilitator Governance Privilige powers that would be blocked through this MIPs prioritization enforcement, then you are absolutely right. This MIP would set a terrible precedent by having MKR voters micromanage the core units and force them away from working on a superior deal, towards working on a worse deal. I completely agree that the information about the conflicting, superior deal should be clearly presented, and then this MIP should be voted down in such a situation if it is really clear and unambiguous. I’m sure Allan, as a maker stakeholder would also agree with this. If the process is clearly reliable and merit based, everyone wins. But on the other hand if no such situation exists, think about the precedent if this deal is voted down after being on the receiving end of such a united front by the core units. Basically we would be voting no on a deal that everyone agrees provides benefit to MKR holders, entirely on the basis on a dispute of technicalities and process that could just as easily be sorted out later, after we have gotten the things done that are ready to be done now. I can see how some people could describe it as looking like a power struggle and IMO that’s not a good look and just overall a setback to maker governance IMO. I could be wrong, but I assuming we can all agree that it’s a no brainer compared to just holding USDC - legal structure designed and verified by christian, bond strategy designed and verified by strategic finance and the overall effect being making some decent income and letting us finally prove we have the means to get rid of large amounts of USDC. The only thing I could see be a question of value in the long run would be the monetalis fee, but that could only be expected to go down through competitive pressure and having more arrangers wiling to hold bonds, which will only happen in the first place if the community shows that its possible to onboard as such using a reasonable process that provides some kind of certainty and clarity.

content.content: Appreciate the response and acknowledgement.     rune:  why that triggered the emotional and personal reactions we’ve seen   Not sure who you are referring to with this, but for me this is coming from a place of genuine concern for how things operate. I’ll elaborate on why I think this differs from previous MIPs in a very consequential way. Up until this MIP, it has been standard for MIPs to provide governance-level guidance to the relevant domain experts, but they have never forced our hand into taking a particular course of action. This changes that, and I don’t think it’s a good business decision.     rune:  It’s not about trust in any individual, it was simply a question of providing Allan and others the best advice on how to make sure these large, potentially important and lucrative deals can most directly deal with the daunting task of attempting a collateral onboarding, knowing how many things have already gotten stuck over the years. I believe in this approach because it provides clarity, transparency and proves we can get things done. The prioritization enforcement means that for the first time ever, the DAO will be in a situation where it can make a decision with a very high level of clarity about the results.       rune:  On the other hand, with a clear prioritization that actually can be counted on, both sides can move in tandem, coordinate and get it done and dealt with and out the door, so Maker can get rid of USDC as quickly as possible, and the core units can move on to the next deal.   Agree with the assessment that we need to be able to provide stronger guarantees to counter-parties. We have been dealing with this issue as Core Units for a number of months now. Negotiations are fundamentally better handled in private, so how to walk that line between getting a good deal, being transparent and having the authority to approve something has been an ongoing challenge. I think the way to do this is to give more autonomy from governance to have relevant domain experts making executive decisions rather than having governance be the guarantees mechanism. Core Units can always be booted out if they are underperforming, and this plays into your Supporting Core Units plan to audit and make sure things are running smoothly.     rune:  I really hope that people can step back from this and take a look at this proposal objectively and see it for what it is - a vote that will allow us to decisively onboard 500 million of no-brainer collateral and finally put a dent in the USDC.   I will hold my judgement until the relevant domain experts weigh in. There has been no due diligence, so I do not consider this a no-brainer.     rune:  IMO if you read the language carefully there should be no question about the due diligence embedded in this proposal.   Glad to hear and your explanation on it being the guarantees of the deal makes sense to me now, but as I said I do not believe this is the role of governance to make these guarantees. It should be the domain experts as elected by governance vote.     rune:  Assuming that MIP65 is approved end of April and fully executed over the course of May       rune:  guaranteed to get fully finalized and executed in May   I think this is maybe an assumption where you are losing people. SocGen has taken 8 months or so to work out a deal, and they are a large, reputable institution. Admittedly I know very little about Monetalis, but from the outside they appear like a startup with a couple of employees and a completely unknown reputation. Executing a loan this size should not be expected to sail through due diligence in a month. My personal preference while in this legal grey area is to prefer borrowers who are highly reputable in lieu of legal enforcement, but if RWF signs off after proper DD and outlining the risks then I am okay with this.     rune:  Basically we would be voting no on a deal that everyone agrees provides benefit to MKR holders   I do not agree to this. I want to see proper DD first, and then I will decide. So should every MKR holder. So in summary, I am okay with proceeding on the path of evaluating this as a possible loan, but the language that forcibly ties the hands of CUs needs to be removed and this should be re-submitted. We have many more well-known entities / protocols coming down the pike. Growth is about to release their proposal for the System Surplus DAI cap raise and PE has been working full force on getting D3Ms up for Compound, Maple and Rari Fuse pools along with finally launching MCD on other chains in Q2. We are not in a rush. We still have a large first-mover advantage and we are accelerating the growth process with a cap raise. Let’s stay the course because it’s working imo.

content.content: Thx for the response. Let me just reiterate, this proposal doesn’t override the need for an assessment, and additionally requires a clear unambiguous verification of the legal guarantees that this MIP spell out, that cover all bases Maker could want. This verification must be done by Christian under the umbrella of RWF, indirectly the elected domain expert on legal matters. And keep in mind he will have full autonomy to provide the verification. It only goes through if Christian is satisfied with the structure. The game theory then dictates that Allan has to let Christian fully design the structure exactly the way he wants it, or there’s no guarantee to Allan the verification will be possible. Similarly for the question of the liquidity and return profile of the rated, public bonds. The final, legally implemented setup must be verified by the Strategic Finance team to “ensure only execution of bond strategies appropriate to use as large scale liquid RWA collateral can be acquired with assets provided to the legal structure by Maker.” Again, Strategic Finance has full autonomy to decide whether to provide this verification, which means that game theoretically allan has no choice but to let them fully design the restriction in exactly the way they want.  I think this is maybe an assumption where you are losing people. SocGen has taken 8 months or so to work out a deal, and they are a large, reputable institution.  I understand why it seems fitting to make this comparison, but I think it’s completely wrong, and comparing monetalis to socgen actually helps explain why this and other deals using similar methods it can be done so fast. SocGen is a deal for actual on-chain bonds, unlike anything Maker has done before and containing all sorts of novel legal and technical challenges. This MIP65 deal is a maximally simple structure based on the basic proven model of the 6s vault, meaning all the questions of creation, liquidations, emergency shutdown, winddown etc are all known and proven in the wild. The structure fundamentally is based on the idea that the blockchain component is as minimal as possible, basically just getting dai into some offshore entity that then injects it to the trust through a broker. Everything on the other side is just a normal cookie cutter financial transaction, nothing novel. We have known have to do this in the community for 9 months at least, we have just not had the process and ecosystem to actually use this knowledge for anything large scale constructive yet. But at this point there is basically nothing we know better in this community than how to do the classic, standard trust structure. And Monetalis has already been engaging with allan for a very long time at this point, it’s basically not possible to get any more prepared for a swift onboarding. And it really should be obvious that a large bank is always gonna do a defi transaction 100 times slower than a startup with experienced financial professionals, even if the bank wasn’t trying to do something complicated. Finally since this is for public bonds, the size of the deal does not impact the timeline. A complex bond strategy could make it take longer, but then Strategic Finance could just elect to pick only short term treasury bonds and have that be the extent of the due diligence. Allan has estimated to me that it would be unlikely to take more than a month, and could probably take less. IMO there is no reason to do a hard commitment to some exact timeline since you can never know the exact last minute hurdles. The important thing is that if it starts to drag out and block other things that are more important than getting a 500 million deal closed (dont forget, this would only be applicable to sub 100M DC), then Allan will have to protect his reputation and the onboarding will be withdrawn. I think the D3Ms are an important thing to consider, and my reaction for a best path forward is that we should request a carve out of specific exemptions to those that right now are transparently planned and being prepared in the other RWA MIPs that are in RFC and are doing prioritization. It’s clear that they are important and can scale to levels equivalent to large RWA deals (at least compound), but shouldn’t be hindered by having to do the full MIP process, and at the same have to begin their life with a very low debt ceiling to accumulate lindy effect. For this deal, we don’t have any option due to the MIP process, but I think in all cases it’s worth it to just make sure we can get the 500 million through. While I think it would have been even better to ensure D3Ms could go through despite this MIP, there wasn’t clarity about these onboardings before the frozen period cutoff occured, I think it’s clearly worth to just get the deal done and then just do the D3Ms as soon as the deal has gone through. We may lose out on a couple of days or weeks worth of lindy effect on the D3Ms, but we will get 500 million of USDC swiftly dealt with.

content.content: rune:  We are no longer some hobby project, we are the scale of billions and that requires working with real businesses that need to be able to reasonably estimate that they will get a positive expected value out of the time, energy and costs of trying to interact with Maker.   And as such, scale can only be achieved through operationalizing the process. When something doesn’t work, we need to fix it. This is about a real problem that needs to be discussed and alignment created. I believe this is one of these situations where the community needs to provide input/feedback and help create the actual solution as this transcends any one core unit. I too want to act as a real business and that means we put the DAO first and do what is best for the protocol. Today, we have a business to run so let’s go do that. It also requires us to examine the sources of information, the level of involvement, and the understanding economic incentives of all parties involved. I appreciate your disclosure as I think transparency is very important especially since you have been a strong advocate/supporter/advisor of this deal.     rune:  Because there currently exists no process that can be trusted to actually work or provide any kind of certainty around timeframe, which makes it unfeasible.   If we want to actually fix an issue, it makes sense not to create it elsewhere. For me, I’d rather we solve the prioritization and commitment issue and not be forced to do that with language inside of a MIP that effectively disables the DAO. If the DAO wants something, let’s be clear on what that is, draft our own verbiage, and vote on it. If we we are unable to do this for any reason, then this continued hijacking of the DAO will happen. I mean, I get it. If I was an investor in Monetalis, the OPM projects, or others that come the DAO’s way, I would work around of the inefficiencies of the DAO. I find economic incentives to be a very powerful motivator and I am all for them…as long as the DAO is creating the rules. The latest round of MIPs do not put the DAO in a position of authority and that is the heart of the matter for me. I want to be clear these are my personal opinions and you may or may not agree with them. From a CES CU perspective, we are committed to finding a solution that works, whatever that might look like, to scale the supply of Dai safely and securely and in the most cost effective manner possible.

content.content: Is there a place where we can see what’s being worked on, where they are in the process, and timelines?  I think part of it is just that it’s not easy to know what’s happening at any one time unless you’re tuned into every single proposal and where they are in the process.  If everyone is clear on current schedule and priorities, then it’s easier to understand where to place new work and how it might affect current work.  It also helps to understand what capacity the teams have for work at any one time.  Maybe you cap the amount of work at any one time so anything else that gets approved is pushed into the future.  But then again, sometimes things happen and current work does need to get pushed aside for the urgent or more worthy.  These are all decisions that can be made through governance but it would be better if everyone knew what was going on. Within this proposal, I know I was focused on the benefits this would provide.  But if it’s brought up that we’re working on the D3Ms and MCD on other chains, I can weigh the benefits of this proposal with that work (supposing I actually understand the benefits and the timelines of the other work). One thing that is attractive about this proposal as presented was that it seemed as if much of the work was already done and things are ready to go.  When considering priorities, shouldn’t low hanging fruit be attractive?  One question I’m wondering is how much work in terms of time this is for the core units.  I understand there’s analysis that needs to be done.  How much work is there for the PE or other teams? I know I have a lot of questions.  I’m sure the CUs understand the implications upon current tasks much better than I do and I’ll likely never understand it as well.  But it would be nice if it was easier to understand what goes on behind the scenes in order to ascertain whether all this pushback is justified.  Again, please educate me if there is something I should read to understand better.  I’ve already learned a lot about the COB process through this post.

content.content: On entrepreneurship (or lack of thereof)     twblack88:  Slightly confused; what are you asking here Seb?   I’m more or less asking if there is a captain in this ship. More precisely (as there is no captain in a DAO), what is the culture on this ship? One big tokenholder is A16Z. Ben Horowitz wrote a very good book The Hard Thing About Hard Things.  An early lesson I learned in my career was that whenever a large organization attempts to do anything, it always comes down to a single person who can delay the entire project.   People always ask me, “What’s the secret to being a successful CEO?” Sadly, there is no secret, but if there is one skill that stands out, it’s the ability to focus and make the best move when there are no good moves. It’s the moments where you feel most like hiding or dying that you can make the biggest difference as a CEO.  The book has at least two examples of achieving stuff under a tight deadline. So maybe my question to delegates is to know if they are ready to do the hard things to make my MKR bags valuable.  Let’s get things done Without short-term bonds, we can’t produce yield on our assets. No one cares about losing 1.5B from the 3pool because we weren’t doing anything with those anyway (and we should feel shame for that). Every month this project is delayed, we are losing $1M+. Good thing that MKR holders have strategic patience as a quality. Without short-term bonds, no capital increase as you will do no RWA nor be confident to be able to invest at scale. Without short-term bonds, we can’t raise the DSR and supercharge our DAI exposure. On the legal side, we have MIP58 - RWA Foundations as a guide. Clydesdale is exactly the same as any RWA will need (with the exception of SocGen which has no economic value in the medium term), yet simpler as there is not much to deal with. Monetalis will not have much power in it so no need to spread FUD about that. On the financials side, I stated from the start that my preference is to do simple safe stuff (very short t-bonds). Is it optimal and safer? No, as illustrated in towards taking asset risks. But let’s get something done and we can improve it down the line. Community will have the opportunity to chose. We can all agree that this MIP suck. It should be obvious that I’m not a big friend of @rune  and seeing him bullied is part fun but part sad. I mean the guy made this protocol that is paying all CUs, own more than half of the hat that protect the protocol and bootstrapped delegates. Moreover, this is one rare time when I agree with him. I see two ways to move forward:  1 - Dropping the MIP and be serious about the work As we all wants the thing to be done, we can act as entrepreneurs. CUs can commit to be serious about prioritization of this work, RWF commit 1M of their 2M contingency buffer to compensate Monetalis if someone on our side is unfaithfully blocking the project. I can commit to yell if someone is not serious about it. @Allan_Pedersen delay the MIP and we fix it for next month (but starting the work NOW) with insurance of the delegates that they will vote it. No games, no politics, just work.  2 - Be creative for the blocked MIPs We vote the MIP. It’s still unclear what important stuff is blocked by the MIP, but PE facilitators can always use their power to pass an executive or an “anon” is submitting the executive (it’s permissionless). All we need is delegates to come up with something and willing to do the hard things. Get with @rune in a call and fix this thing. I’m no entrepreneur but I’m willing to do the hard things. Happy to hear better ideas. Let’s get things done together without delay. PS: To finish with another quote of the book, let’s not end up like that:  At a certain size, your company will do things that are so bad that you never imagined that you’d be associated with that kind of incompetence. Seeing people fritter away money, waste each other’s time, and do sloppy work can make you feel bad. If you are the CEO, it may well make you sick. And to rub salt into the wound and make matters worse, it’s your fault.

content.content: @rune given you were the prime actor to remove @SebVentures and nominate @williamr to head RWF I would think that you would have been well positioned to understand the desired mechanics of RWA process here (the rest of the CUs not withstanding).   governance has been waiting for RWF, Legal, and Oversight to finally approve any one Asset originator or RWA deal.   What I keep hearing as a delegate is: that existing already with DC pipeline is ‘insufficient’ in structure.   This means Centrifuge/NewSilver DC is stuck,  6s DC effectively stuck.  Monetalis unsuitable for many reasons.   I have asked repeatedly on structure of pipeline with RWF and have gotten varied and changing answers   This is difficult, and never been done, etc.etc.   RWF, legal, and Oversight have been very clear about how Monetalis does not fulfill certain requirements.  I listed a few of these in my post.   So from the RWF CU standpoint Monetalis as per MIP65 at least as I have had to interpret their tea-leaf posts on the subject is a no-go. Also it has been made clear, if governance approves this MIP, that the event would be significant, set a bad precedent and be destructive to MakerDAO generally.   The structure of this MIP - specifically in the language that prioritizes Monetalis, halting work on anything else under 100M, and putting anything else over 100M into some queue behind Monetalis to many is excessive and a MIP criterion that I will not be supportive of.   I as a delegate (and others I believe) have been very clear, give us ANY deal that passes muster with RWF, and the other CUs and within a reasonable DC range and we will happily approve it. I want to respectfully ask a basic question to you @Rune regarding the energy you are putting into lobbying and reasoning for passing of Monetalis, while leaving New SIlver/Centrifuge and 6s, SocGen, Huntingdon to quietly navigate. While I have made public issues I have had with RWF, most of what they are bringing to the table with respect to RWA reviews and criterion are ‘reasonable’ and appear for the most part to be ‘fairly applied’.    Governance and MKR holders can disagree by basically putting up for offboarding either individuals or the unit, make the case and get governance to back it.  But I think given you have personally recommended @williamr, and for all intensive purposes RWF has signaled that Maker can do better than Monetalis with respect to a 100M deal, I wonder what has happened that you feel governance is properly suited to take affirmative action here, when those who, with experience, and expertise are tasked with being the experts on this subject are to be ignored.? If you feel governance should bypass RWF on this for Monetalis, then why are we avoiding NewSilver/Centrifuge and 6s?   What is so much better about Monetalis than 6s, or Centrifuge, and by what basis would you encourage delegates and/or MKR holders to bypass the paid experts on this important subject for MakerDAO? When I come down here I honestly want to extend DC on all of our existing players because most of them are already here working with Maker and have been waiting, working patiently, at great expense I might add.   Do a 50M Centrifuge, 50M 6s, and 50M monetalis.   I mean if governance is being encouraged to bypass RWF and go ‘balls to the walls’ to break the RWA log jam why not distribute the risk before taking on another 50M elsewhere? Why must we go for 100M btw, why isn’t 50M good enough, etc. I am going to be as bluntly honest here as possible.  Today in the G&R call I watched GovComms put together a kind of report on MakerDAO CU activities (thank you so much btw GovComm) why can’t we get a similar report on RWA so everyone can know where we are at here.   I grow tired of this ‘trying to be considerate’ in obscuring real status of our RWA queues and to my mind is disingenuous towards our RWA applicants (that we will deal with them in a timely manner).   We have Pando thinking in MIP73 that 6s legal structure is good when we have RWF telling governance to DC 0 that.   The total mismatch in communication and expectations with respect to the most important collateral type RWA, with the greatest potential for growth is mind boggling. Everyone wants to see this move somehow and no-one can honestly figure out where we can move, how, with whom. I may be slow here, and admit I can be dense, but I for one as a delegate am looking for clarity in RWA/RWF like I got today with GovComms on projects.  Someone please help me out, or put me out of my misery.!

content.content: Totally on board with teams not spending all their time defending themselves.  I really think a simple solution is to keep an up to date roadmap with clear schedules and timelines.  People will be less impatient if they understand what’s happening and when to expect it to happen. This proposal is still unique because the other ones you mention (HVB, Pando, and OPM) do not address treasury bonds which are a different asset class with a different risk profile.  In a way, you could see it as a different RWA category to be thought through.  Using terms from the ALM framework, treasury bonds present significantly lower asset risk, market risk, credit risk, and liquidity risk when compared to other real world assets.  This should come at the cost of lower returns but when you compare them to the currently supported or proposed RWA collateral, the returns for short term bonds are very comparable.  This is why there is a little more passion on this post because the opportunity is clear.  To be fair, counterparty risk still exists and I think most of the pushback in this proposal focuses in on this point along with getting the process and prioritization right.  Because of counterparty risk, you can’t just throw everything you want to invest into one proposal.  But I think the community does see the value in this idea and hopefully there will be more proposals similar to this in the future so the risks can be spread out to multiple counterparties.

content.content: I agree @Traster_Tray, as I mentioned in my post above (here) that in principle this is a lower risk strategy, carrying very limited liquidity and credit risk - but with significant basis / interest rate risk and execution risk in size. The in principle caveat is most important. This ad hoc MIP has the ambition of being self-contained, meaning that it provides already all the required elements for MKR holders to take a decision. This is where I disagree. The current MIP covers only a high-level view of the strategy, albeit one we all agree on. However, to ensure that the strategy does indeed carry very little credit/ liquidity risk and has limited execution risk, much more colour needs to be done on what partners Monetalis intends to partner with (not having Monetalis any bond management experience) and what is the exact strategy. In a post above Allan already hints at actually running credit risk in the strategy (below).     Allan_Pedersen:   am curious about the proposal from the asset manager but I am also nervous. A treasury portfolio should not, in principle, carry significant credit risk and a cross-over proposal IG-HY to squeeze a few bps of yield I believe doesn’t go in the direction of reserve diversification and yield improvement that an initial treasury portfolio should have.  Here our views on the risk absorption capacity of the balance sheet may divert, but, as above, this is not the time for personal opinions or speculation. It is time for establishing data and analysis on the subject such that the community can make an informed science and data-based decision.   The ultimate point is that, although we all agree this strategy to be of extreme importance and, when executed well, carrying far less risk than off-chain collateral onboarding, we believe that the discussions would still have to run a proper onboarding process to ensure all domani teams providing their opinion. Given the size of the ask it shouldn’t be an issue to make sure things are properly done without the overhanging threat of blocking the whole system. I am happy to see that @Allan_Pedersen and the Monetalis team are acknowledging it as well. content.content: Okay, understood and no more argument from me.  I’ll be looking forward to see how this all evolves with the new proposal.

In most cases at best you can create an expectation of offboarding facilitators if they fail to perform their duties, but this has to be triggered manually and would only rarely happen in response to a single specific task. content.content: christiancdpetersen:  @rune - really? Are you suggesting that core units cannot interact and address/resolve common issues? We will never get anything done if this is the intention.   No, definitely not. I was just trying to make the point that in public everyone will clearly take a stand for transparency and discourage hidden decision making. But the (right now necessary) reality is that most critical decisions and discussions occur and are decided behind the scenes, with the public interactions usually being less important. That’s fine, nothing would happen if that wasn’t the case and radical transparency is not something that just develops by itself because it really has no precedent. The problem is when the situation of behind the scenes decisions is denied. The instinctual unwillingness to reveal hidden decision making mechanisms is what has the potential to create what’s known as the tyranny of structurelessness if it is not addressed in time. I’m working on addressing it myself, so I’m not talking about this just to cry about the sky falling, really just wanted to point it out in action. It’s common sense that plenty of direct and private interaction needs to happen all the time in a DAO for anything to get done. It should also be common sense that separation of powers, radical transparency and disclosures must be enforced in order for a DAO to remain a DAO over the long run, once our initial group of highly trustworthy founders start to be replaced by a future workforce that we cannot expect to trust to the same degree. The two things are compatible, but it has never been done before and is a major challenge. I hope to be able to help the community evolve to that point where we can make it.

content.content: I am trying to read all the comments on this thread but there are so many. Let’s try and keep it positive. Big things are coming.

Threads like this tend to be difficult to fork cleanly, because users reply to both on-topic and off-topic subjects when they make replies. I would strongly recommend using the flagging functionality to highlight anything off-topic, such that it can be default-hidden in the thread. I’ve just made the flag icon default-display in the post footer so it’s easier to find.  image838×167 8.58 KB  At this point given the scale of the forum, we need to rely on the community to communicate what is and isn’t acceptable via the flagging system, there are multiple options, including an ‘off-topic’ selection.

Dear all, As potential facilitator of a Lending Oversight Core Unit I have commented on MIP65 already, here. I believe that Monetalis can be a great partner to help the DAO diversify its treasury book, in accordance with the guidelines indicated by Strategic Finance and supported by the community. I believe also that it will be crucial to assess the ultimate manager of Maker’s assets. We have seen that Monetalis intends to partner with Baillie Gifford to do that, and I think BG is the type of institution that we should attract. As a reminder Monetalis IS NOT a bond trader, but an intermediary for Maker, therefore before approving or allocating significant amounts through the MIP65 proposal, we should underwrite BG itself and not Monetalis’ capabilities only. I believe this won’t be an issue, given BG’s pedigree, but something that will have to be done in case the proposal gets approved. I am looking forward to support the team the best way I can in case this proposal gets approved.

content.content: Allan_Pedersen:  Legal Structure and Governance Appropriateness Verification The Real World Finance Facilitator and the “in SES incubation” Facilitator of Legal and Transactions Services must, through a public forum post, provide a Verification of the legal and governance structure appropriateness for holding a large amount of low risk real world asset collateral for Maker.   @prose11 I am recommending an amendment to MIP65 based on changes related to responsibility in the performance of the legal work for this structure. The MIP65 was originally drafted with a scope in mind which is currently changing as per funding requests by other core units: CES and SF. With that in mind, it is only natural that the accountability for verifying performance of legal duties is also amended to reflect the changes in responsibility for undertaking the work. Or at a minimum supervising that the legal review is done in accordance with best practices. Given RWF is not engaging the legal contractor to perform the review on MIP65, it is natural it should not have the responsibility for supervising its proper execution. I am therefore requesting that governance aligns the accountability for verification of legal & governance structure with the responsibility of performance of the task of legal review. Therefore placing the accountability with the responsible core unit, whichever team contracts the legal services for this MIP. Thanks, William
